Reported by The Age, ABC News Australia, 9News

items.title: ‘He’s blacked out’: Demolition derby car ploughs into crowd at NSW show
items.standfirst: Terrifying footage shows the car crashing through a fence and hitting spectators at a showground in NSW, injuring 11 people.
items.content: Terrifying footage shows the car crashing through a fence and hitting spectators at a showground in NSW, injuring 11 people.

items.title: Spectators injured when car crashes into crowd at rally at NSW showground
items.standfirst: Nine people are hospitalised after a car crashed into spectators at a rally event in regional NSW on Saturday night.
items.content: Nine people are hospitalised after a car crashed into spectators at a rally event in regional NSW on Saturday night.

items.title: Multiple hurt, man fighting for life after speedway car hits crowd
items.standfirst: NSW Ambulance said 11 people had been injured, including one man who is fighting for life.
items.content: Multiple people have been injured in an accident during a demolition derby in NSW.One person, a 54-year-old man, was fighting for life after a car crashed through a fence and into spectators at the Walcha Motorcycle Rally in Walcha, 420 kilometres north of Sydney, about 6.20pm yesterday.NSW Ambulance told 9News that 11 people had been injured, while NSW Police reported on nine who had been taken to hospital.READ MORE: Teen charged after pregnant woman and unborn baby die in Sydney crashBystanders rendered assistance before paramedics took seven men and two women – all aged between 20 and 75 – to Walcha District Hospital. Those nine include the 54-year-old man.The 54-year-old and three others most seriously injured "are expected to be transported to major hospitals overnight", police said.Police said the speedway car had been competing in a race when it crashed through a fence and hit a mobile grandstand.They said officers had been told the 27-year-old driver was involved in an on-track collision immediately before his vehicle crashed through the fence.NSW MP Brendan Moylan said the vehicle had been taking part in a demolition derby as part of the Walcha Motorcycle Rally."Thank you so much to the ambos, the police, the SES and everyone involved for their swift and incredibly professional work at the scene," Moylan said in a post on Facebook."Like all of us, my thoughts are with everyone affected."The Crash Investigation Unit will examine the scene later today.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.content: Nine people have been injured after a speedway car crashed into a crowd at Walcha Showground.

Nine people were hospitalized after the crash.

clusters.title: Bullets sprayed into home in Sydney's south-west
clusters.neutral_headline: Shots fired into home in Sydney's south-west

items.title: Bullets sprayed into home in Sydney's south-west
items.standfirst: An investigation is now under way after a "targeted" shooting at a home in Casula in Sydney's south-west.
items.content: An investigation is now under way after a "targeted" shooting at a home in Casula in Sydney's south-west.

items.title: Home sprayed with up to 40 bullets during 'targeted' shooting in Sydney
items.standfirst: Police were called to a property on MacKellar Street in Casula about 2.20am following reports shots had been fired into the home.
items.content: An investigation is under way into a "targeted" shooting after a home in Sydney's south-west was sprayed with bullets early yesterday morning. Police were called to a property on MacKellar Street in Casula about 2.20am yesterday following reports shots had been fired into the home.Multiple rounds had been fired into the empty property, police said.READ MORE: Trio of teens charged over alleged violent carjacking READ MORE: Donald Trump vows to sue the BBC for billions of dollars It is understood up to 40 shots were fired before the shooters left the scene. Police believe the shooting is targeted.NSW Police Superintendent Scott Tanner yesterday said it may be linked to organised crime.Tanner also had a blunt message for the alleged offenders."There's only two outcomes for the people who are involved in this, and that is they'll either go to jail or be dead," he said.READ MORE: The political scandal every Australian PM is at risk of repeating Nobody was home at the time of the incident and there are no reports of any injuries.The family previously living at the home moved out weeks ago to begin renovations. Investigators said a black Audi was seen driving west along Leacocks Lane following the incident.READ MORE: Aussies pay Maheer up to $5000 for what is hidden in his mouthFamilies on the street have been left shaken. "I didn't sleep after that. You don't expect that that close to home, that's not on," one neighbour told 9News ."We've got kids. As soon as I heard it, I covered his ears so he didn't wake up."Anyone with information is urged to contact police or Crime Stoppers.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: Shots were fired into a home in Casula, Sydney.
The shooting is being investigated as "targeted".
Police were called to the property around 2:20 AM.
Approximately 40 bullets were fired into the home.
The incident occurred on MacKellar Street.

clusters.title: Trump threatens to sue BBC for up to $US5bn over documentary edit
clusters.neutral_headline: Donald Trump Threatens Lawsuit Against BBC Over Documentary

items.title: Trump threatens to sue BBC for up to $US5bn over documentary edit
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump has threatened to sue the BBC for up to US$5 billion over a documentary edit despite receiving an apology.
items.content: US President Donald Trump has threatened to sue the BBC for up to US$5 billion over a documentary edit despite receiving an apology.

items.title: Trump vows to sue BBC for up to $7.7bn over documentary edit
items.standfirst: "We'll sue them for anywhere between a billion and five billion dollars, probably some time next week. I think I have to do it," Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One.
items.content: aprilU S President Donald Trump has flagged his intention to sue the BBC for up to $US5 billion ($7.7 billion) over its documentary edit, despite receiving an apology from the broadcaster.The BBC apologised to the president after airing an edited version of his speech on January 6, 2021, splicing two parts of his address which took place almost an hour apart.In a letter to Trump, the British broadcaster's chair Samir Shah personally apologised for the edit of the speech and accepted it "unintentionally created the impression that we were showing a single continuous section of the speech".READ MORE: The political scandal every Australian PM is at risk of repeating READ MORE: Teen charged after pregnant woman and unborn baby die in crash Trump's lawyer had previously sent the BBC a letter demanding an apology and threatened to file a US$1 billion ($1.5 billion) lawsuit.The president said he still plans to sue the BBC, potentially now for a much larger sum. "We'll sue them for anywhere between a billion and five billion dollars, probably some time next week. I think I have to do it," Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One."They've even admitted that they cheated."The legal dispute was sparked by an edition of the BBC's flagship current affairs series Panorama, titled "Trump: A Second Chance?" broadcast days before the 2024 US presidential election.A third-party production company spliced together three quotes from two sections of the 2021 speech, into what appeared to be one quote in which Trump urged supporters to march with him and "fight like hell."READ MORE: Australia's beef industry welcomes Trump's sudden backflipAmong the parts cut out was a section where Trump said he wanted supporters to demonstrate peacefully.Trump earlier declared the BBC was "fake news", adding that the people of the UK are "very angry" about the edit.He said he would raise the issue with UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer."I'm going to call him over the weekend. He actually put a call in to me. He's very embarrassed," Trump said. Director-general Tim Davie, along with news chief Deborah Turness, quit on Sunday, saying the scandal was damaging the BBC and "as the CEO of BBC News and Current Affairs, the buck stops with me."DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: Donald Trump plans to sue the BBC for up to five billion US dollars.
The lawsuit concerns a documentary edit, despite an apology from the BBC.
Trump made the announcement to reporters while aboard Air Force One.
The potential lawsuit could be filed sometime during the following week.
Trump stated he felt compelled to pursue legal action against the BBC.
